Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n><n>### Response:		E<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:Sitting to close while watching TV can cause what sort of pain? Choices:  A: brain problems B: laziness C: get fat D: headache E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demostration:<n>### Explanation:<n>Sitting to close while watch TV can cause:<n>Brain: This occurs when one has to change the position of their head often when watching TV or if they are not watching TV at all because they cannot do anything else.<n><n>Laziness: This occurs when one does not use their eyes properly and ends up feeling lazy after a long time watching without moving at all.<n><n>Get fat: This occurs when one eats snacks while watching TV without realizing it, resulting in getting fat.<n><n>Headache: This occurs if one does not sleep properly at night or does not take regular breaks from watching TV, resulting in headaches.<n><n>Laughter: This occurs due to various reasons such as watching happy movies, comedies, etc which make people laugh out loudly.<n><n>### Input:(1*2)=2<n><n>### Demoscation:<n>Divide 2 by 2, which we did in our last class in the last equation like this<n>```<n>Input: (1*2)=2 <n>Output: 1<n><n>Input: (1+2)+3 = 6 <n>Output: 4<n><n>```<n><n>Note: (1*2),(1+2), and (3x1*2) are all the same thing.<n><n>The output 2 and 1 are the results for dividing by 2 and the output 4 is the result when we add 3 to 1.<n><n>The result of 2 is the remainder, and the total is what was left over after the division.<n><n>

For example, if "Jenna" and "Tony" both have birthdays on Tuesday, there is another birthday (like a parent's) on the same day as theirs.<n><n>### Input<n><n>```python<n><n>from math import floor<n><n>def my_function(x):<n>    print(floor(math.sqrt(x)))<n><n>i = input("Introduce your value: ")<n><n>my_function(int(i))<n><n>```<n><n>Result :<n><n>```<n><n>Introduce your value : 34.45852<n><n>The result is : 9<n><n>```<n><n>### Your code:<n><n>```python<n>from math import floor <n><n>def my_fun(x):<n>    return floor(math.sqrt(int(x))) # return<n><n>i = input('Introduce a number: ')<n><n>my_fun(int(i)) # Use a for loop to print the returned solution (i.e. the return is 9<n><n>```

The price of one apple and two bananas is also $1.20, as is the price for one apple and three bananas. As you select more items, how much do they cost?<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: For the first apple and three bananas it costs $1.20 but it goes to $1.80 for two and change<n><n>### Answer:<n>Answer:<n>```<n>1. 10 <n>2. 10 11 5 <n>   - + = (10 X 3 *4 11 X 2 *8  5 X 1000  )<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:Mom is tidying a house, where would she put the loose dictionary? Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demonsration:<n>Input: Freddy and Corey are counting a bowl of candies. Freddy has 11 and Corey has 1 more than  Freddy. How many does Corey have? (Input a number that would be entered into the computer.)<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Question:<n>* What will your code do?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input Freddy and Tapanga both have the same number of candies. Fredy has just one more. Corey has 2 more than both of them. Who has the most?<n>Answer: Tapanga<n><n>### Question<n>* What will your computer do?<n><n>## Solution<n>* TDD <n>  * Create TDD with a new function to count<n>  * Test a function<n>  <n> ![Task image 1](assets/images/tasks/task-1.png)<n><n>### Part 1<n>```python<n># Task 1<n>def count_candies(n1, n2):<n>    return n1 + n2<n><n>def check(test_number, actual_ans):<n>    assert test_number == actual_ans, test_number<n>```<n><n>## Solution: Part 3<n>```Python<n># Task 1:<n># Freddies Code<n>def count_candy(n1, n_2, n_3):<n>    a = n1<n>    b = n_2<n>    c = n3<n>    while a is not equal to b is not equal to c is not equal to 9:<n>        if a is not equal to 0:<n>            a -= 1<n>        elif b is not equal to a:<n>            a -= b<n>            b -= 1<n>        else:<n>            a -= c - 1<n>        if b is not equal to 1:<n>            b -= a<n>    else:<n>        return a<n>    a -= b<n>```<n>```Python<n># Tapanga's code<n>def count_candidies(n1,n2,n3):<n>    if n1 is less than or equal to (7) and n2 is greater than or equal to (1) and n3 is greater than or equal (1) return 0<n>    else:<n>    return n1+n2+n3

Choices:  A: football stadium B: laboratory C: baseball stadium D: pharmacy E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>Input:The child pounded her mitt in excitement while enjoing her first game in the bleacers where A: football stadium<n>Answer: B: laboratory<n>```<n>## Hints:<n>### How to solve problem1:<n>![1](./Images/input.gif)<n><n>### How to solution problem2:<n>![2](./Images/2.gif)<n><n>![3](./Images/3.gif)<n>

However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:The spoiled child's playroom was massive, but only one of many rooms in the what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when in a race? Choices:  A: lay eggs B: eat fruit C: wrestle D: compete with each other E: draw pictures<n><n>### Response:		A: lay eggs<n><n>### Explanation: Correct. Humans do lay eggs when in a race!<n><n>### Response 1: B: eat fruit<n><n>### Expectation: The correct answer is A because humans do lay eggs <n><n>### Response2:C: wrestle<n><n>### Expected: The correct was B because humans do eat fruit.<n><n>### Response3:D: compete with eachother<n><n><n>### Excluded: The incorrect answer is D because that does not relate to the instruction.<n><n>### The following multiple choice question has 4 wrong answers.<n><n>### Which one of these choices is a correct answer to the following multiple choice question?<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### The correct number is 0<n><n>### When she was younger Emily rode her horse every day. When she was 18 she rode for a week a year, then rode one day a week when she was 25, and finally 4 days a week right before she was 30.<n><n>### If she rode 1 hour 30minutes each time she rode on a week day and half an hour each time she rode on weekends, how many years did it take for her to ride for the first time for her to ride for four days a week?<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>1. years<n><n>1. months<n><n>1. Days<n><n>1. hours<n><n>### Exclusion: The correct answer is years because Emily rode for 1 hour 3 and 30 minutes each time she rode on the weekdays and half an hour on weekends, which would require her to ride for 1 year per week.  <n><n>### There are two problems with the question as it stands<n><n>### Exclusive<n><n>### There should be a way for the user to specify the length of each day and so it should be an option instead of a hardcoded constant.<n><n>### Experimental <n><n>### The problem is that the question is trying to impose that the only possible solution is 1 hour 3 minutes each day on the weekend, and 4 hours a day for the other days of the week. If Emily rode 1 hour a day every day for 3 years she would have ridden 18 years
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:What happens to people playing games? Choices:  A: winning B: entertainment C: happiness D: cheating E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>---<n>#### Resources<n><n>- [MDN JavaScript documentation - strings](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String)<n>- [MDN Object destructuring](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/docs/web/javascript/reference/operators/destructuring-assignment/)<n>- [MDN Loops](https://developer.mdn.mozilla.org/fr/docs/Web/API/Iteration_Objects_and_Methods)<n>

He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:What could be happening near you if the ground is getting wet? Choices:  A: solidifying B: melting C: getting cold D: feeling cold E: skin rash<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**Input 1** [what could be happening near you, if the ground is getting, wet]<n><n>**Response 1** [It could be that the ground is solidifying.]<n><n>**Input 2** [If you were to add water to the glass, does the glass gets bigger or smaller?]<n><n>**Response** "Gets bigger"<n><n>**Input 3** [What could be happening to your clothes, if it was very hot and dry.]<n><n>**Response** [It could be you clothes are getting dry.]<n><n>### Input 4: The number of the room, the number of the floor, the number of the building and the number of the street.<n><n>### Response 4:<n><n>Input:**4**<n>[The number of the room]**5**<n>[The number, of the floor]**4**<n>[the number, of, the street]**1**<n><n>### Comment:<n><n>The student answered the prompt accurately and explained the method used to find the answer. <n><n>### Next steps:<n>Students will receive a copy of this assessment, as well as an explanation of how they performed, so that they can understand what they did well/what they need to work on.<n>

How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:What is a living thing with a lip? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:When I was home, I was comfortable.  But I had a crippling fear of going where? Choices:  A: outside B: vacation C: idle D: apartment E: neighborhood<n><n>### Response:		<n>Inside Idle<n><n>**Explanation**: "where inside I was comfortable" (the "I" is a subject here, rather than the "was", which is a descriptive that goes with the pronoun). The noun that the pronoun "I" goes with is usually the noun in the second part of the sentence in each case.<n><n>### Input<n>1. I was comfortable where I home.  But I had<n><n>### Response<n>Outside I was comfortable.<n><n>**Explanance**: The answer is "outside", and here's why: "home" is a noun, so the pronoun has to be "I". "was comfortable where" indicates the clause in the sentence is a relative clause containing "home", which is the noun being modified by "where". "but I had" is a main clause modifying "I was comfortable" and containing the subclause of "where I home". This is what the pronoun modifies: "where I home" (note that where goes with the sentence, not where I home). The noun "where I home" is the subject of a transitive verb, so it needs a direct object. That object is the entire clause "was comfortable where I home." "was comfortable" is also a prepositional phrase, so "I" goes with "was." "Idle" would be incorrect, because the question doesn't contain an "e" in "Idle", and because "home" is singular, and so "where" would end with an "s". <n><n>Comment: I know this is a duplicate, but a lot of users are confused as to why there are two examples. If you really think there should be one, then you need to edit the second example, and add two sentences to the first.<n><n>Comment: @JayZawaski: What if I want to show two examples, one with a multiple choice question and one without?<n><n>Comment: It doesn't work that way. Every answer must include an example, a demonstration and an instruction. If there are multiple forms of an instruction, multiple answers can be given (this is the format of [this answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/9873847/1686241), for example). That answer, for example, uses a different answer format. For these types of questions I

How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He hoped that choosing secular upbring would help the result be unpredictable. <n><n>You can use the [Answer Checker](https://github.com/Azure-Samples/cognitive-services-sample-for-python/blob/master/answer-checker/README.md) to help you with your submission.<n><n>### Submit Your Code<n>* Please submit an individual response according to the guidelines and criteria presented in this assignment.<n>* Please submit your response to this assignment within 1 week of the due date so that your instructor can make proper assessments and offer suggestions to help you improve. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:At a state fair judging pigs requires careful what? Choices:  A: verdict B: judging C: responsibility D: evaluating E: prejudice<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  C: responsibility A: verdict D: evaluating E<n><n>There are 100 bubble gum containers in a vending machine, 10% of these<n>contain blue gum and the rest contain pink gum. You select a vending container at random, pick it up, take out the<n>bubble gum, and examine it carefully. What is the probability that the<n>gum in the container is blue?<n><n>A.<n>> The gum is probably blue so choose to leave the gum.<n><n>Input:What is the probability that the gum in the container is<n>blue?<n>> There are only 10 in the whole vending machine, so the probability is 0.1.<n><n>Answer:A: There are 100 containers, so this is 1/10th, or 10%. Since we are not considering the color of the containers, take 10% of the 10%, or 0.1 of 0.1, resulting in 66.666666. If our gum is pink, that is correct because we took the gum out and looked at it.<n><n>B: We could say it is a bit more than a chance of one, but not more than a chance of 6<n>Choices:  A, B D E<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Felix has six red pens and three blue pens. If he<n>takes a pen out at random, what is the probability that<n>it is a red pen?<n><n>A. Probability is 6 in 9.<n><n>B. Probability is (6/10)*(3/10).<n><n>Answer: A & B: Both A & B are options for probability.<n><n>Answer: A: You would use multiplication because you are dividing the red pens and the whole pens:6/9 x 3/9 = 6/9<n><n>B: You would use multiplication here as well, like A. 3/9 * 6/9 = 6*3/9<n><n>Answer: A probability is 6 in 10<n><n><n>### Answer<n><n>A: There are 6/10 red pens and the rest are blue so there is one out of four probability, which is the same as 1/4

He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:Some might say that if you want to do something that results in changing society then you need to start from within, to do this what would you be doing? Choices:  A: riots B: vote C: change yourself D: social activism E: change clothes<n><n>### Response:		A: riots<n><n>### Reasoning:Answer 'A'<n><n>1: Bribe<n><n>> You cannot bribe me.<n><n>2: Blackmail<n><n>> He blackmailed her with a threat to tell the police.<n><n>3: Coerce<n><n>> His boss coerced him into signing the contract.<n><n>4: Force<n><n>> He forced the door open with a tire iron.<n><n>5: Intimidate<n><n>> She intimidated her students with strict discipline.<n><n>### Input<n>> Bribe: A<n>> Blackmail: C<n>> Coerce: E<n>> Force: B<n>> Intimidate: D<n><n>### Revision of previous answer<n>Some might say that if we want to change ourselves then we need to change our mind set (A) or actions (E). This is incorrect, because if you change someone else then that will not have much impact on changing society. Society does not always change when someone goes outside our self because it may only be the surface that appears to have altered (C) and the actual change (D) may be in-effective (F)<n><n>### Instrument:<n>Some might say that there are things that a woman can do to make herself feel like a woman and that the rest of society should learn to make women to feel more comfortable in their skin. A: dress like a man B: wear makeup C: not have facial hair D: get your hair to look like a man E: wear women's clothing<n>### Choices: ____, ____<n><n>### Revisions<n>Some might say that we ought to allow women to dress in male clothing as it is one way the woman can "be herself" (A) or that there should be no difference in the clothes worn by a man and woman (C). Although both A and C are true statements, there are also things that a man can do to feel himself (B). To change society one must consider that there are things that have changed within society and not just the behaviour of a small subset of individuals (D).<n><n>### Choices<n>__, ____, ____, _____<n><n>### Instructor feedback<n>Choices must be A B C D E.<n><n>Choices must be B C E.<n><n>Choice order must be

Put the bread slices on the table with the vegetables, and add <n>the spread to each slice.  <n><n>3) Wrap and seal with tape:<n>  a) Take three slices.<n>  b) Spread with a thin layer of spread.<n>  c) Wrap two slices:<n>  1) Pull one slice in half.<n>  2) Wrap these half pieces with another piece.  <n>  3) Cut any remaining excess.<n><n>4) Arrange a piece in the wrapper, and place on the table. <n>Fold back the other wrappers so that they're hidden and secure.<n><n>### Response<n>Put these steps in order 1, 2, 3 or 4 to make a sandwich.<n>### Example<n>2,1,4,3<n>### Answer<n>1,2,4,3<n>---<n>### Instrucions:<n>### The word 'Teacher' is a word<n>### Write two words which have the same meaning as the word 'teacher'. Choose from: teacher<n>### Example: teacher: student: classmate<n>### Answer: student and classmate are the two words that are synonyms of 'teacher'<n>---<n>### Writing is like painting. The two languages have the same rules for what can be done:<n>### One must:<n>  * use all of one's colors for painting<n>  * use all types of punctuation marks for writing<n>  * make all the letters the same size if one is drawing with texta<n>The difference, though, is that whereas with painting, the finished product is to have colors (i.e., 'the picture'), in writing the finished product is to use all of one'a colors.<n><n>### Which words do not have the meaning 'to make a picture to paint?' However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>function numberOfCards(player1, player2){<n>	var n1 = player1.played.length;<n>	var n2 = player2.played.length + 1;<n>	var winners = [];<n>	for (var i = 0; i < n1; i++){<n>		if(player1.played[i]==playertwo.played[0]) winners.push(player1.playername);<n>		else if(player1.playeds[i] == player2.players[0]) winners =player2; else if(player1.player[i] == playertwo[i]) winners.push("it was a draw");<n>	}  <n>}<n>```<n><n>### Explanation<n>```javascript<n>function numberOfCars(player1, playertwo){<n><n>}<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: bright B: pointed C: correct D: acute angled E: clear<n><n>### Response:		A, if something is obtuse, it couldn't be bright because the angles of obtuse angles are all acute angles except for the the two angles adding to 90 degrees and there's at least one angle acute (less than 90 degrees) so the angle can't be bright. All other answer have acute angles including the the angle that's 90 degrees, so they can't be obtuse angles either.<n><n>Demonstration:<n>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U_U_GlCkGUM<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:The human looked down longingly as he sat in the orbiting space station, what did he miss? Choices:  A: nearest house B: workplace C: surface of earth D: office block E: his feet<n><n>### Response:		What does the task want you to do?<n><n>### Input (code):The human looked down longing as he sat in the earth station, which he miss? Choices A: nearest house B work place C surface earth D office block E: his shoe <n><n>### Response (code)<n>```javascript<n>//Step 0 Start<n>let x,y,z,numberWords;<n>let words=["nearest","house", "work place", "surface", "earth", "office block","his shoe"]<n><n>//Step 1<n>let theName=prompt("which word do you want? input any word to get the answer");<n><n>//Step 2<n>x=parseInt(theName);<n>if(["nearest", "surface"].includes(x)){<n>  z = x + 23;<n>}else {<n>  z = 4 + x + 3.5;<n><n>}<n>if(["work", "office"],[],["block", "build"].includes(x)){ <n>  //y = x - 10;<n>  if(["work", "block"].includes(x)){ y = x - 11; } else {y = x + 15/2}// x 24<n>}else{ y = x + 50/2;<n>if(["surface"],["earth"].includes(x)||("office"].includes(x)){y = x + 25;}}  <n><n>if(["near by", "next door"].includes){<n>  //z = x + 20<n>}else{ y= x - 15;<n> if(["earth", "surface",].includes(`work`)){<n>  //y = 2; } else {y - 6}<n>}<n><n>//Step 3<n>z = Math.round(z) > 80?z - x:z<n>console.log(x,y,z, numberWords)<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>The human looked down longly as he sat in the space station, what did his miss?<n><n>### Response<n>What does the task want yo do?<n><n>## Tests<n><n>### Input 1<n>The human looked down as longingly as he sat at the space station, which he missed? Choices: A:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:Sam left his muddy shoes in the entryway.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: department store B: school C: garden D: office building E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>If Sam would leave his muddy shoes away from the entryway, he would be in either the house or garden. I think Sam would be in the garden.<n><n>If Sam would leave the muddy shoes in a department store, then he would be in the department store.

Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		<n>The vacation might be relaxation, enjoyment, and travel
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. The numbers of crows that came from the west is half the number that was there before they came from the west. How many crows were there when the crows from the west came?<n><n>### Response<n>After the crows came from the north, there were 53 crows in total. Then the number changes to 67 crows again after the crows from the West came. After the crows from the south came, there's only 46 crows in total so the number changed twice in total. So the number of crows when the crows from west came is 48 crows.<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>Input: Tapang and Corey have 59 candies together. Choices:  A: insane B: annoy people around C: enjoy D: inhale E: had good voice<n><n>### Response:		Input: "If 'inhale' or 'have good voice', it's wrong. If 'insane', 'annoy people around' and 'enjoy' are 3 different option. So, "Insane"? The other option is "annoy people around"<n><n>### Input:"What does this mean?<n><n>### Response:"If you say that option A is the first answer then the first option is already in B, or C is the second answer, it means the other two options are in D"<n><n>### The last Instruction<n><n>Input:How to choose the right answer: a. I choose option A<n>Answer: I choose option B, because if I choose A, B is already in A.<n><n>### Input 2:How to choose the correct answer:<n>A. I say option B <n>B. I choose option C <n>C. I choose option D

Choices:  A: shopping mall B: hospitals C: populated area D: school E: military base<n><n>### Response:		<n>In a theater with unpaid actors only theaters.<n><n>### Exactly what does it mean to have an input?<n><n>```txt<n>(c) - input is also known as an expression in Python<n>```<n><n>### Examples<n>```txt<n>c. input(x) -> c x<n>```<n><n><n>### What does it mean to have multiple choices of answers?<n><n>```txt c<n>```<n><n># Challenge:<n>We are tasked with writing code that outputs a string that represents an animal's name. You will be taking input from a user in the form of an animal class. The input will be a type, and a number. The type can either be cat (lower case) or dog (also lower case). Dog's age starts at 6 and ends at 9, cat's end at 4 and start at 2.<n>```css<n><n>- An animal class<n>  - name: "Dog"<n>```<n><n>**Challenge questions:**<n>1) What class will the code first be executed under?<n><n>***Answer: "Class"***<n><n>2) What does a method look like?<n><n>```txt css<n>class animals()<n> {<n>   method(name, age)<n>     def this = name + " at age "+age<n> }<n><n>Animal = animals({"Dog", 9})<n><n>Animal("Hector", 9).method<n>```<n><n>**Output:**<n>"Hector at age 9"<n><n>3) What class name does the Animal constructor use?<n><n>***Answer; animals()***<n><n><n>4) Is name an instance variable?<n><n>***Answer***<n>Yes. Instance variable cannot be accessed outside of it's class. It is an instance variable in a class animals.<n><n>Instead of Animal, you can use this = Animal because animals is a class.<n><n>5) What is name in the above output the value of?<n>```txt<n>"Hector at 9"<n>```<n><n># 6)<n><n>You must use the method method() to output the answer with what you have in your code.<n><n>### Challenging yourself<n><n>```txt css <n>- This is just a basic overview of what is required in python.<n>```<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Using your notes from the previous exercise, write

The dog ran away. The boy went to the store with his mom and dad. He saw a cat who followed him home. He petted the cat. He ran away.<n><n>### Response<n>Input: The boy was at the store, the dog was BROTHTERLY and the cat was the BOY'S.<n><n>### The words were put back into the sentence, making it all one word. Your response should only be one word.<n><n>### Word order choices:<n>Input:The boy was at the store. He saw a dog who followed the home him, mom and dad. The dog ran away the dog who followed him home, the cat was older than he. He petted cats, who followed the cat who followed him home, there were two and the dog.<n><n>### Solution:<n>BROTHTERLY<n><n>### Instructino: Choose a word to complete each sentence.<n><n>### First set of words:Choose a word from the box to complete each sentence. The given word must be used in each position. The box contains one or more words. <n><n>### Inputs: Choose ONE word from each sentence.<n><n>Input:He was very tired after his shift at the restaurant. She felt a pain in her chest. After that, she called 911.<n><n>### Second set of words:Choosing a word from the box will be very difficult. The choice

Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Justification:<n>This is the correct answer, <n>I choose B because he has a lack of anything to balance the  cup and has no skill to balance the cup.<n><n>### Input :The boss came in a few minutes after the new employee finished his first job.  No wonder.   No one had worked there for years.  He didn't even have a desk. Choices:  A. too long B. enough C. a lot D. enough E. plenty  <n><n><n>### Input  : 	A. the correct number of students are available.   B. the correct number of teachers available.   C . There aren't enough teachers for the right number of students. D . We don't have enough staff to handle all of our students. E. The students have to be satisfied with fewer teachers than we originally planned.  <n><n>### Response :<n>A<n><n>### Justifcation:<n>If the number of students is correct the first job that a new employee must do is to look for the right number of teachers. If the number of teachers is correct the job is done. But if there isn't the correct number of students then they don't have the correct number of teachers, then there isn't any right number of students, in which case the job isn't done.<n><n>### Response  :<n>D<n><n>### Justfication:<n>This is the right answer,<n>I choose D because there is  enough students for every teacher, they have enough students.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:You might head to the locker room after getting a green drink here. Choices:  A: health club B: jocks C: fitness centre D: stadium E: gymnasium<n><n>### Response:		The choices you have here are health club, stadium, and jocks<n><n>### Rationale:<n>You can answer these questions using one of four strategies:<n><n>1. **Subset Test**: Consider the choices in this exercise. Which pairs of choices are subsets (not members) of the same list? (Think: If some choices on this list are subsets of other choices, then we can't have any choices that are subsets of every choice.)<n>2. **Premise Test**: Consider the list of pairwise choices here. Can you find a premise that proves or disproves one of these pairs of choices is a subset (not a member) of the list? ("If A is a subset of B, then A has a subset that is a member of B.")<n>3. **Counterargument**: If you think that one choice is a subset of another choice, or the other way around, can you create a counterargument where you prove that each of these choices is _not_ a subset (not a memeber) of the other choice? (If we cannot create a counterargument, our answer is incorrect!)<n>4. **Contradictions**: If choice A is a member of choice B, can you create one contradiction for each of the choices in this list such that B _does not_ contain any of these contradiction? (If we cannot find any contradictions, our answer is incorrect)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. Choices:  A: stressful B: dangerous C: fun D: illegal E: deadly<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>Input:How many times does the sun rise in a day? Choices: 0: once 1: 15 2: 483 times 3: 8650 times 4: none of these<n><n><n>### Instructions:Complete the code below.  <n><n>```<n>import random<n>import numbers<n><n>i = 1<n>count = 0<n>while i <= 10:<n>    r = random.randint(1, 10)<n>    while r <= i:<n>        i -= 1 # decrement because it runs from "i" down<n>        count += 1<n>    if r > i:<n>        print(“i”,”r”,“count”)<n><n>```<n><n>### Output: i 3 r 4 count 2042.4<n><n><n><n>### Hint:<n><n>1. i is incremented instead of decremented <n>2. The output will not return a number<n><n><n><n><n>## Solution (B):<n><n>Below we show you how to complete the code based on the instructions.<n><n>Input: i = 1<n><n>1. Decrement rather than increase<n>```<n>for variable in ['name']:<n>    variable -= 1 # this will always subtract 1 from the string<n>```<n><n>Input:  while r <= i<n>```<n>for variable is r:<n>    while r <= "i":<n>        r -= 1 # this decrements r each time it goes around the loop<n>        i -= 0 # this will increment i each time is goes around the loop<n>```<n><n>## Output:<n>```<n><n>"""<n>This is Example of using for loop for reducing and while loop for increasing<n>"""<n><n><n>import random<n>def ExampleofReducingandWhile_Incrementing(value=100,minimum=1,maximum=0):<n>"""<n>Run a while loop and a for loop for reducing and increasing<n>"""<n>for variable in ['value']:<n>    variable += 1 # this will increment variable by 1 each time we go around the loop<n>    while variable >='minimum' and variable <='maximum':<n>        variable -= 1 # decreases value by 1 each time the while loops goes around<n><n><n>print("The example of for loop

Choices A: Stay at the balcony B: Wait for the bride at the exit C: Follow the bride<n><n>Answer:<n>I will choose ''C''<n>because if the groom is in line at the exit, then the bride and/or groom will come out of the exit.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>I have to wait at exit because I can see the bride and/ or groom<n><n>### Input<n>Raymond said "Give me a chance. I promise to give you 100$ if I win. But if you lose, you will be the dog. You think I'm kiddin'? I'm not." Whom does Raymond want to play poker with? The remainder after the last process becomes your birth year.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>if the number is 1, then the remainder is 3. 3 will be divided by 4 then the remainder is 1. 1 will be divided by 2. 0 and remainder will be 0.0=2022<n><n>### Exlarnation:<n>3 divided by 4 will be the answer.<n>1st answer is 0.75<n>2nd answer is 0.1666<n>3rd answer is 0.04.<n><n>### Task<n>Linda can solve a math problem using three different mathematical operations: subtraction, addition, and multiplication. John has developed a method of encrypting and decrypting data.  Below is the text of one file, in its original form.<n><n>> _When a man is tired of London, he is tired of life._ <n>_A man cannot be a success unless he is a good man._ *<n><n>### John has not yet developed a way of encrypting the first sentence. Instead, he is considering replacing it with the second sentence. John already knows that the first sentence and the second sentence are interchangeable and can be used in any order with each other.  John also knows that he must not change anything else in the file. One of the sentences cannot be used in the other’s place.  Which sentence should John use in the file?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>1. Input:  The file’s text in its original form. This string of characters is the data that John has to encrypt, not the sentence he will replace the first sentence with.<n><n>Answer: <n>Because it contains words he can use to encrypt and decrypt the first sentence.<n><n>2. John’s decrypted text.<n><n>Input: A: _Why should a man not be trusted to tell the truth?(Hazlitt, 1825)_  B: _Everybody has his faults.  My greatest fault is that I am too fond of it.(Nathaniel Hawthorne, 1861-3)_ <n><n>4. The sentence John will use to replace the original sentence.<n><n>This sentence was selected as it was one that did not include words that could be used to encrypt the first sentence.<n>

He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:To learn must have the right book, to work efficiently what must one have? Choices:  A: improve yourself B: become knowledgeable C: have tools D: persistence E: have more knowledge<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answers A through E will be the only choices. You will need to write a complete sentence (including proper grammar and spelling) with the correct number of words and an APPROPRIATE answer (answers with a few exceptions, such as when there are no answers given) for the statement written above. Please keep you sentence from looking similar to an algorithm (i.e. IF then, ELSE, while, do, while, for, next etc.). Your answer can be in any format but must have the correct number of words with an appropriate answer as the goal of the exercise. Keep the sentence in context to the task.<n><n>### Response Guidelines:<n>* Be sure to answer the question.<n>* Keep your sentences structured with proper grammar and use good spelling.<n>* Only use the available answers A through E, in that order.<n>* Answer the questions with an appropriate answer.<n>* Answer the question completely including the suggested words.<n>* In a perfect world, the response should be at least 10 words long.<n>* Use the question to help you write your sentence<n><n>**Experience: If you are already familiar with the topics and feel that you can handle the questions without any assistance, feel free to move on to the next task.<n><n>## Task: Task 2 - Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.

How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. Choices:  A: home B: hardware store C: home D: hot room E: office<n><n>### Response:		<n>C:<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>How many points would you like?<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>One please.<n>```<n><n>## Challenge<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes the challenge. Write a response that uses a code to appropriately complete the request.<n><n>>**Marcus is not sure how to find the highest prime number. So, he creates a program that will search every number from 10 to 1000 for the highest one.**<n><n>### Instructions:Use your program to find the highest prime numbers between 10 and 75.<n><n>### Input Data<n>```<n>I will enter 20 for the number between 10 to 75.<n>```<n><n>```<n>The program starts searching the first value for the highest number. It uses numbers as references.<n>```<n><n>>**A:**<n>```<n>I will set the value to 11 and the reference to zero.<n>```<n><n>#### Questions<n>```<n>Is the value greater than the reference (or 0)?<n>```<n><n>> **B:**<n>```<n>No, the number is smaller than 0.<n>```<n><n>The program uses the value to determine which direction to go. For this problem, <n><n>```<n>If the value is a prime number, the program uses the next step<n><n>If the value is not a prime number, the current step will be skipped<n>```<n><n>>  **C:** <n>```<n>The value is prime number.<n>```<n><n>This step only happens once, so the program moves to step 2.<n><n>Now the next part of the process is to search for a number greater than the highest prime number. This requires the program to use the reference, which was 11 in this case. If the next number is a prime number, that will be the new reference.<n><n>For example, if the next number is 13, then the reference is set to 11 and there will be a new step 2. On a negative value the program needs to do the same thing in a backwards direction.<n><n>>  **D:**<n>```<n>13 is not a prime number.The program goes to the next step.<n>```<n><n>Next, the program will print the values. This uses a `print()` method.<n><n>> !!!

How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:What is likely to have more than one level in a city? Choices:  A: carpenter's shop B: video game C: garage D: total number E: building<n><n>### Response:		C) garage<n><n>The carpenter's workshop is only one floor. The video game is also located on a single floor. The garage is also built inside the house. There are only three options that are found on the building's first floor. The top-most floor is the floor where the building is constructed. It is difficult to determine the number of stories since there are only three options. Therefore, the correct answer should be given after considering all possible factors.<n><n>### Input<n>Billy loves watching videos, but he doesn't have a subscription. How many minutes are there in a minute? Please type your answer to the question below.<n><n>### Response<n>1.0<n><n>There are so many minutes within a hour that are 1.0. 1 hour is the sum of 58 minutes.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Billy loves reading, but he doesn'y have any subscriptions. He doesn't also know how many minutes are within a minute. He therefore has many questions about how many minutes there are. He is also thinking about which plan would be best. He needs money to buy his favorites.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>Billy is watching a video one minute in one year. However, he doesn't know if there are other people who haven't seen the video yet. He also notices that each second lasts only about 30 seconds.<n><n>### Problem<n>How many minutes are there in 1 hour? Choices: A) 45 B) 12 C) 58 D) 2<n><n>### Solution:<n>45. 45. 48 are all the same in all other cases.<n><n>### Solution<n>45. 1. 47. 58 D.<n><n>### What are the possible answers for the first option?<n>A) 45 D) 2<n>B) 58 E) 45<n><n><n>### Answer: A.  58 D.<n>

Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		The answer is A<n><n>### Input Question<n>How do we calculate 50%of a number?<n>### Solution<n>1). First determine if the answer is odd or even<n>2). then calculate 0.5(number in question)<n><n>### Input - Choices<n>We can give either odd numbers for even numbers and we can give either numbers 5 or 10 but we want the answers to be either odd or even for that to happen you need to take half of the number and then you get that out of ten<n><n>### Solution<n>Input - Choices<n>-10<n>5<n>-5<n>0<n>-1<n>5<n>0<n>6<n>2<n>You can figure out from each of the two answer choices what to take, you can figure which numbers are odd and even and which numbers are odd and which are even.<n>The only way the two answer choices can differ is if they are even or odd, so you take half of 10 and for that case the answer is 5 which is even<n>so the second half is -5 which is odd<n>the second part has no changes but it is odd<n><n>

What kind of a help is John providing? Choices:<n>• A. Farm animal feeding<n>• B. Field preparation<n>• C. Haystack harvesting<n>• D. Harvesting<n>E. Grain and seed processing<n>• F. Livestock management<n>• G. Farm supply pick-up<n>• H. Food preparation<n>• I. Other<n><n>When selecting your answer you can choose more than one answer. You do not need to write an example sentence with each answer you give.<n><n>### Other instructions:<n>1. Select and describe a scenario that requires a task for completion. Give details about the task that need to be done and what the person needs to do it.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### Demonstration Input:<n><n>#### Input:<n><n>A: Farm animal feeding<n><n>#### Response<n><n>#### Instructions<n><n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:What do people in the same family often share? Choices:  A: brown hair B: names C: two eyes D: will E: brains<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you think of each person in a family as having the same genetic code, then people in the same family are likely to share the same eye color, and hair color.<n><n>``` ruby<n>def answer_question<n>family = gets.strip.chomp.split(" ")<n>if family[0] == “B”<n>p “Brown Hair”<n>else<n>if family[0].to_f >1 then<n>p “Brains”<n>elsif family[0].pluck("a...z") == “N” then<n>p “A name”<n>else<n>p “EyeC color”<n>end<n>end<n>end<n>answer_question()<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>```ruby<n>def answer_question()<n>puts “Hi there! What do people in the same”<n>puts “family often share?”<n>family = gets.chomp.split()<n>puts (family.size > 1)? family : “nothing”<n>end<n>answer_ques_1 = gets.chomp #Input<n>answer_ques_2 = gets.chomp<n>answer_ques_3 = gets.chomp	<n>answer_ques_4 = gets.chomp……<n>```<n><n>#### Input:<n>```ruby<n>input = gets.chomp(31)<n>answers = gets.chomp()<n>```<n><n>#### Output:<n>```ruby<n>if answer is true then say “Yes”, else say “NO”<n>#Answers.size.times do answer= gets.chomp; puts “#{answer}”<n>```<n><n>#### Demostration: <n>For the above solution, we read one string, which is the input and print a random number from 1 to 3 in the same line(like 0361, 0745, 0957 etc.) Now the question is that after reading the input, how many times we have to read to print 3 numbers? For example, if the input is '0625' then we should read it 6 times as the second number is the same as first and so on.<n><n>### Sample Solution:<n>### Program:<n>```ruby<n>#!/usr/bin/ruby -w<n>string=gets.chomp<n>count=0<n>for i in 0..string.

Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		(the correct answer must be an integer)<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blank so your computer code makes a sentence.<n><n>Example:<n><n>If you have 10 cents and buy one cookie, and another one costs 35 cents, how many can you buy with that amount?<n><n>When using a loop program:<n><n>How many times will you have to repeat this program in order for it to complete the task?<n><n>When using an if program:<n><n>If you flip a coin 4 times, and it always lands on heads for each flip, what is the probability that it would land on tails for at least one flip?<n><n>When using switch:<n><n>What will choose which program will run, based on one condition?<n><n>Example:<n>Let’s use the switch program to make two sentences.<n><n>When using for:<n><n>Which program will run if the for loop can find n, where n <= 20, n >= 1, and n is an integer?<n><n>Example: When using else:<n><n>What will it do if the if command can't find 5?<n><n>Ex. "If the for loop can find x where x <= 20, x >= 1, and x is an integer?"<n><n><n>Example: If you want to print out how many candies you have, using a loop, do you need to use for, while, or repeat?

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:The woman picked from an apple tree while surrounded by other trees, where was she? Choices:  A: illinois B: woods C: new york D: indiana E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		C, new york<n><n>### Justification:<n>The farmer's market in New York is the only one that has apples.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>* First the condition: 'the apple tree while she surrounded by other trees', is in the sentence 'A woman picked an apple while surrounded by other trees.'<n>* The woman has picked the apple tree from New York is surrounded by other trees in New York.<n>* In the sentence 'other trees', I think the 'other trees' is the tree beside the apple tree. And the woman was surrounded by other trees.<n>* There was no other trees outside the apple tree, so no need to pick the apple tree to the woman that has surrounded by other trees. So the answer is C.<n><n><n>### Instructions: A store clerk counts a basket of lemons. She counts each lemon once and does not count twice any lemons that are in their own bag or separated in some other way. Counting a lemon takes 30 seconds. How long does it take to count all of them?<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: It takes 200 seconds to count all lemons<n><n>### Justifications: <n><n>200 seconds = 30 * 6 min <n><n>### Examples:<n><n>Input: The time it takes to count all lemons is 720 seconds.<n><n>Output: 12 min<n><n>### Instunction: <n>A farmer must drive to each of his 5 separate farm plots and spread fertilizer on each plot. After spreading fertilizer on the third farm plot, the farmer realizes that he forgot to bring his fertilizer, so he must drive all the way back to the farm house to get it. If it takes him 5 minutes to get his fertilizer, how long does it take him to return and spread the fertilizer on each of his 5 plots?<n><n>### Justition: I believe the answer is 120 minutes.<n><n>### Justifictions:<n><n>After he got the fertilizer: (5/6)*50 mins<n><n>(5 + 6) * 50 (to arrive at 5 farmlands)<n><n>(5+(5 + 6))*50 : 5 minutes to go to the first

However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by only a few people recently? Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		A

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:The king was to meet an ambassador, where would the meet? Choices:  A: court B: dinning room C: throne room D: monarchy E: castle<n><n>### Response:		E<n>```<n><n>#import data/inputs/input_data<n>##########################<n>data_path = '/Volumes/SSD/data/'<n>input_path = '/VolSdDss/data/inputs/'<n>##################<n>print("I import ", data_path, " data. Now I move from ", data_path, " to ", input_path)<n>##################<n>os.system("mv", data_path, input_path)<n>output_path = './output/'<n>###################<n>csv_file = input_data/input_path +'import_day=1-6-2019.csv'<n>json_file = input_path +'import.json'<n>####################<n>if os.path.exists(csv_file):<n>    data = pd.read_csv(csv_file)<n>    d_json = data.to_dict()<n>    #####<n>    with open(json_file, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:<n>        json.dump(d_json, f, ensure_ascii=False)<n>    ###<n>    return 'done'<n>else:<n>    ##########<n>    return "No data " + filename + " found at provided path"<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:The little girl was raised selfish, she didn't even care when she was doing what? Choices:  A: crack B: antipathy C: being mean D: disinterest E: unfeeling<n><n>### Response:		Answer: Option B<n><n>### Instructor notes: A task should be short and unambiguous. It should not have the answer and should not use terminology or vocabulary that is unfamiliar to the listener. A listener would then either know the answer or be given sufficient time and instruction to find it out. Answer choices should include an unacceptable or incorrect answer. Note that all task content and instructions must be presented in the target language (T), even if this includes giving the unacceptable responses. A listener should never be given enough input to identify the correct answer by himself because the question or problem is too general. An acceptable answer is always given after each choice.<n><n>### Sample instructions:<n><n>* [T] You buy 12 apples. There are twice as many apples as oranges. How many oranges do you have?<n>* [T] A man walks into his friend's room. He puts the lamp on a table. There is a chair in front of the bed. He takes two books from the shelf and gives one to his friend. He picks up a cup with a drink. He makes coffee. Then he sits down on the same chair and drinks it. Then he stands up. He looks at the clock. He's angry. He puts down his cup and shouts. He picks up his cup and drinks the coffee. He looks at the watch again. He gets up, turns on the TV. He sits down on a chair and leaves the room at 3 o'clock.<n>* [T] Which one of the following pairs are not opposite?<n>    * Right / Left<n>    * Huge / Tiny<n>    * Young / Old<n>    * Cool / Warm<n>* [T] I give you a dollar, two cents and two quarters. How much money do I give you?<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:What can happen to you when eating hamburger from someone that you do not know that does not happen when you usually eat a hamburger? He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		A  <n>

(2) A line is count in a line.<n><n>## Output:Write two examples of the output that you will see under different circumstances.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>If the input is "a: from the sky" the correct output is "C".<n>Another example for the output would be:<n>if the input would be "B" the correct output would be "E".<n><n>### Input Examples:<n>* "A: from the sky" The correct output is "D".<n><n>### Response Examples:<n>Ex:<n>"A: from the sky, B: map, C: cross counties, D: country, E: michigan"<n><n>### Explanation<n>In B, you will use C:<n><n>In C, you will use E, B, C, and D:<n><n>During the map task, the student created a diagram of the given instructions involving the steps.<n><n>The student stated that map will show all the roads.<n><n>The student noted that you will be crossing the country by car so you will need roads.<n><n>In the response, the student stated that a line is counted as a line. This statement is incorrect. One sentence should not contain two adjectives.<n><n>The student also added that the line is "counted" in the line. This also is incorrect, and should be taken out.<n><n>The steps to use for this question are listed below. The correct output for the instructions is also included.<n><n>- (1) Count the number of lines in grid, (2) Count<n><n>### Expected Output:Write two examples that you will expect.<n><n>### Example:<n>A: from the sky - I expect for the correct output to be "D"<n><n>C: cross counties - i would expect for the correct output of be "C"<n><n>### Response for Example:<n><n>"A: from sky - D"<n><n>"C: cross counties- C"<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostrations:(1)

If the number of 3 is true, the while statement checks whether the value of i is larger than or equal to 0. If i is smaller than 0, i should be incremented by 1 and the while check should be repeated.   If the while statement is true, the for check should execute the code.<n><n>### Write a program that asks the name of a person and then asks the name of a group. The total is $29.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Due to the simplicity of the problem, it could be a "trick" question, where the answer was not the clearest, but was meant to trick the player.<n><n>### Sources:<n><n>https://www.pexels.com/photo/brown-cat-sitting-on-surface-3753280/<n>

Choices:  A: boot B: the desert C: loaf of bread D: foot E: hock<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:Write a block of code that correctly interprets and outputs the data.<n><n>### Example 1:<n><n>### Example output:<n><n>### Input 1:<n>| "name": "Ari",<n>|    "diet": {<n>|         "breakfast": {<n>|             "breakfastItem": {},<n>|     "breakfastCategory": {<n>|         "$": {}<n>|    },<n>|     "weightLost": {}<n>|    }<n>| "active": false,<n>|    "dinner":{<n>|     "dinnerItem": {},<n>|    "dinnertCategory": {<n>|        "$":{}<n>|    },<n>/      "weightGained":{}}}<n><n>### Example Output 1:<n><n><n>```js<n>var people = {<n><n>    people: [{<n>            name: "Ari",<n>            diet: {<n>                breakfast: {<n>                    breakfastItem: {},<n>                    breakfastCategory: {<n>                        "$": {}<n>                    }<n>                },<n>                active: false,<n>                dinner: {<n>                    dinnerItem: {},<n>                        dinnertCategory: {<n>                            "$": {}<n>                        },<n>                    weightGained: {}<n>                }<n>            },<n>            weightLost: {},<n>                weightGained: {},<n>    ],<n>```<n><n>### Example Instruction<n>Given an object, return a new object where the keys correspond to the weight gains/losses and the values are the corresponding weights. The empty string will be used as an empty value for weight Gains and weight Losses, and the object will return as a nested object.<n><n><n><n>### Example Input 2:<n><n>### <n><n>### Example Solution Input 2:<n>```js<n>    <n>```<n>### Example Solution Output 2<n><n>```js<n>     var newObject = {<n>         name="Ari",<n>               weightGained:"10",<n>               weightLost:"98",<n><n>         diet:{<n>             breakfast:"7,5",<n>             dinner:"5,5"<n>            <n>         }<n>```<n>### Instruactions:Write a JavaScript program, in the console, to calculate the sum of the two values together.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:James was looking for a place to buy bitcoins.  He searched and found a large menu of what? Choices:  A: advertisement B: news C: bar D: cafe E: internet sites<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Below is an instruction that describes how to do or perform a task. Write a program that follows the directions and completes the task.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Tapanga and Corey are playing a game of Tic-Tac-Toe. They each choose a line, starting with their first letter. If the line they’ve chosen has already been taken by the other player, no points are awarded. This goes on until one of the players has three in a row. Each player scores one point when a row is filled. Write a program that plays the game for Tapanga and Coreys, given their first letter.<n><n>### Inputs:  Line letter for Tapanga Tapanga's points Corey's points Line letter for Corey<n>### Results:  Game Results<n>### Outputs:  Game Results<n><n>### Instructor:<n>Use the following letters when you choose the first line for Tapanga or Corey:<n><n>A-R: Tapanga<n>L-Z: Corey<n><n>Use the following letters for each player's points:<n><n>0-9 = Points for Corey <n><n>10-29 = Points for Tapanga<n><n>### Demo 2<n><n>Danny’s team is planning on winning the school soccer tournament. They’re trying to decide who their kicker will be to win the soccer team their match. They can choose Arya or Chelsea to be their kicker. Arya is a good and reliable kicker, but he has never had experience winning a soccer match at their school. He has practiced kicking many times. On the other hand, Chelsea is a rookie kicker, but she has the experience to kick a goal. Which one of these two players would you choose to win the match for them and why?<n><n>### Input/Results:  Input from the teacher: Danny's team selected Arya as their kicker.<n><n>### Coding Requets:  Do the required steps in the programming template. This template should have at least one output and one input from the teacher.<n><n>### Outputs/Results:  Inputs/Results from the teacher:<n><n>### Instrtuctions:<n>Your supervisor has called a meeting to discuss

Reading a newspaper will give you education from your community and world.<n><n>input:How do you know whether you were using gas, oil, wood or electricity to cook something?<n>choice A:You open the container and check the label.<n>choice B:You pour the food into a bowl or pot and see it cook.<n>choice C:You taste the food to see whether it is done yet.<n>choice D:You listen to the stove to see whether the thing is done.<n><n>### response:D<n><n>### Input<n>The gas is blue, the electricity is red, the wood is green, the oil is purple.<n><n>### Response<n>When you cook something, if it is done, you will know it is oil or electricity. When you taste it, it will let you know if it is blue, green or purple. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input:After attending school for twelve years what do you do? Choices:  A: inspiration B: much work C: boredom D: graduate E: degree<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice was B, much work.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: Which month has the fewest number of days? Input: Which month has the longest number of days? Input. Which month has the exact middle number of days? Input answer: February<n><n>### Response<n>The only month, from the possibilities that the user entered, with an exact middle number of days is February. It’s the only month with an even number of days (28) - if we assume that the question doesn’t mean the 28th day; and it’s the only month that can be either the first or the third month (Jan&Feb can’t be grouped or neither of them could be first, nor Feb&Apr), which allows it to be both the middle month and the month after the third month (it couldn’t be considered the middle month of January instead of February, because that only leaves either the first or the last month - not the middle month).

If he responded "a", he would have a C. <n>    The student would need to write a correct response.  <n>- #### If the answer is "D", it means that he selected both 'C' and 'B' as correct responses.  <n>He would have a 15% for this question.  <n><n>### Conclusion<n><n>You can use this script to give students a question based on time, date, or location.<n><n>### Important<n><n>Note that this script is looking for the student to respond to the question.<n>This script is based on multiple choice options as well as a correct response. <n><n>### Author<n><n>[![Shawn](https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/261238?v=4)](https://github.com/shawnwang131)<n><n>### License<n><n>`[The MIT License](./LICENSE)`<n><n>### Question ID<n><n>**question_**
